{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox artwork | image =[[File:OLB Recall at Bradford Beach December 13, 2011.jpg|300px]] |caption="Holders of the Light" above Lincoln Memorial Drive, adjacent to Lake Michigan in Milwaukee, advocating the recall of Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, December 13, 2011 | painting_alignment = | image_size = | title = Overpass Light Brigade | alt = | artist = Lane Hall, Lisa Moline, Joe Brusky and collaborators | year = {{Start date|2011}}–present | type = Electronic, performance | city = Milwaukee, Wisconsin | museum = | coordinates = | owner = }}
'''Overpass Light Brigade''' (OLB) is an activist collaborative [[public art]] project based in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], and organized by American artists [[Lane Hall (artist)|Lane Hall]] and [[Lisa Moline]] and photographer [[Joe Brusky]]. The artwork is an episodic [[performance art|performance]] originally created as part of the [[2011 Wisconsin protests]] to raise awareness about the campaign to recall Governor [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]].<ref name=MLS>{{cite web|last=Schumacher|first=Mary Louise|title=Overpass Light Brigade Targets Scott Walker|url=http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/entertainment/143260066.html?ipad=y#!page=3&pageSize=10&sort=newestfirst|website=Art City |publisher=JSOnline|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> OLB was co-founded by Hall and Moline. Brusky, a [[community organizer]] and co-founder of [[occupy movement|Occupy]] [[Neighborhoods of Milwaukee#Riverwest|Riverwest]], soon joined the project and facilitated its continued growth and social media presence.<ref name=spark>{{cite web|last1=Schneider|first1=Pat|title=Overpass Light Brigade's illuminated protest signs spark a national network|url=http://host.madison.com/news/local/writers/pat_schneider/overpass-light-brigade-s-illuminated-protest-signs-spark-a-national/article_43ea3818-751c-56d5-90c3-c09ef97f28bb.html|website=The Capital Times|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref>
==Description== The artwork consists of a series of [[Light-emitting diode|LED]]-illuminated plastic panels, each of which displays one letter of the alphabet. Performers, known as "holders of the light," assemble in a line with each person holding one letter.<ref name=Palermos>{{cite web|title=Striking Palermo's Workers to Join Overpass Light Brigade for Historic Bridge Action|url=http://occupyriverwest.com/news/olb-stands-in-solidarity|publisher=occupyriverwest|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> OLB performances present timely messages or political slogans. The Overpass Light Brigade performs at night to increase visibility. Members typically make arrangements for performances and disseminate documentation via [[social media]] platforms.<ref name="Forward Press Release">{{cite web|title=Overpass Light Brigade, Filmmakers Host Screening at Historic Oriental Theatre|url=http://www.wispolitics.com/1006/130311Forward.pdf|publisher=WisPolitics|accessdate=April 6, 2013}}</ref>
Hall manufactures the panels in his shop.<ref name=Kaufman>{{cite web|last=Kaufman|first=Dan|title=Lights in Oak Creek|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2012/08/lights-in-oak-creek.html#slide_ss_0=1|website=The New Yorker|publisher=New Yorker News Desk Blog|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> He describes his process on the ''[[Daily Kos]]'' blog to encourage others to use the group's tactics.<ref name="Make Diary">{{cite web|title='Make Diary': DIY LED Signs to Light Up the Night|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/11/18/1037625/--Make-Diary-DIY-LED-Signs-To-Light-Up-The-Night|website=Daily Kos|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> Photographs taken by Brusky and collaboratively-produced videos are distributed by the group members and fans on the Internet.<ref name="Forward Press Release"/> Brusky joined Hall and Moline in March 2012, to help with social media and the live-streaming of bridge actions.<ref>{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Kirsten|title=Charge of the Overpass Light Brigade in Wisconsin|url=http://blogs.seattletimes.com/uwelectioneye/2012/05/30/wisconsin-anti-walker-protestors-rally-support-with-christmas-lights/|accessdate=April 6, 2013|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=May 30, 2012}}</ref><ref name=OnMilwaukee>{{cite web|last=Brevväxling|first=Royal|title=Overpass Light Brigade mixes social media, "physical commitment of real people"|url=http://onmilwaukee.com/buzz/articles/overpasslightbrigade.html?viewall=1|website=''OnMilwaukee.com''|accessdate=August 10, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Miner>{{cite web|last=Miner|first=Barbara|title=From 'Recall Walker' to 'Question Austerity': A Movement Continues|url=http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/purple-wisconsin/view-from-the-heartland.html?tag=Overpass+Light+Brigade&ipad=y|website=Purple Wisconsin: A View from the Heartland|publisher=JSOnline|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Pabst Palermo">{{cite news|last=Pabst|first=Georgia|title=Palermo boycott organizer files complaint against deputy|url=http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/news/167611785.html|accessdate=April 6, 2013|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=August 27, 2012}}</ref><ref name="OConnell">{{cite web|last=OConnell|first=Kit|title=Overpass Light Brigade is Challenging Free Speech Restrictions|url=http://my.firedoglake.com/kitoconnell/2012/11/13/olb-challenging-speech/|accessdate=April 6, 2013}}</ref>
The Overpass Light Brigade often organizes its nighttime demonstrations on bridges and highway overpasses.<ref name="NYTimes photo">{{cite web|last=Mahon|first=Narayan|title=Rallying in a Flash|url=http://nytimesagency.com/preview/NTA2012033158210|website=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Agency Photos|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> It also mobilizes members to participate in political rallies and vigils. Actions have included collaboration with national labor advocates regarding Walmart's labor practices,<ref name="Walmart Strikers">{{cite web|last=OConnell|first=Kit|title=Nationwide Overpass Light Brigades Join #WalmartStrikers|url=http://my.firedoglake.com/kitoconnell/2012/11/24/nationwide-overpass-light-brigades-join-walmartstrikers/|accessdate=April 6, 2013}}</ref><ref name=OurWalmart>{{cite news|last=Lockwood|first=Denise|title=Protesters Head To Walmarts To Support Employees Trying To Unionize|url=http://greenfield.patch.com/articles/protesters-head-to-walmarts-to-support-employees-trying-to-unionize|accessdate=April 6, 2013|newspaper=Patch|date=November 23, 2012}}</ref> the Chicago Teachers<!-- Group's official title has no apostrophe.--> Union (CTU) strike,<ref name="OConnell"/> environmental advocacy with organizations such as 350.org and Global Climate Convergence,<ref>{{cite news|title=Bill McKibben and 350.org on the 'Do the Math' Tour|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/pictures/bill-mckibben-and-350-org-on-the-do-the-math-tour-20121120/overpass-light-brigade-0084009|accessdate=April 6, 2013|newspaper=Rolling Stone}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Guide to Imagining Light!|url=http://globalclimateconvergence.org/organizing-resources/guide-to-imagining-light-april-25-beyond/}}</ref> and social justice causes, including police violence, indigenous rights and related issues.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Whitten|first1=Cameron|title=MY FREEDOM RIDE STARTED IN FERGUSON. I DIDN'T EXPECT WHERE IT WOULD END|url=http://bitchmagazine.org/post/my-freedom-ride-started-in-ferguson-two-month-anniversary-mike-brown|website=Bitch Media|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Quirmbach|first1=Chuck|last2=Lorenzsonn|first2=Erik|title=Milwaukee Police Chief Fires Officer Who Shot Dontre Hamilton|url=http://www.wpr.org/milwaukee-police-chief-fires-officer-who-shot-dontre-hamilton|accessdate=March 8, 2016|date=October 15, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Zeese|first1=Kevin|last2=Flowers|first2=Margaret|title=Indigenous Nations Are at the Forefront of the Conflict With Transnational Corporate Power|url=http://www.truth-out.org/opinion/item/19445-indigenous-nations-are-at-the-forefront-of-the-conflict-with-trans-national-corporate-power-that-affects-us-all|website=TruthOut|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Eidelson|first1=Roy|last2=Lyubansky|first2=Mikhail|last3=Malley-Morrison|first3=Kathie|title=Building a Racially Just Society: Psychological Insights|url=http://www.truth-out.org/opinion/item/27602-dangerous-ideas-how-our-core-beliefs-promote-and-prevent-progressive-change|website=Truthout|publisher=Psychology Today}}</ref> Appearances have also have included picketing with striking [[Palermo's Pizza]] workers,<ref name=Palermos /> a pedestrian bridge to the [[Milwaukee Art Museum]],<ref name=MLS /> an event with [[Nuns on the Bus]],<ref name="Nuns on Bus">{{cite web|title=Nuns on the Bus to Join Overpass Light Brigade and Palermo's Pizza Worker Picket Line|url=http://occupyriverwest.com/news/nuns-on-the-bus|publisher=occupyriverwest|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> and vigils mourning the [[2012 Wisconsin Sikh temple shooting]]<ref name=Kaufman /><ref name=France24>{{cite news|last=Singh|first=Amardeep|title="Nous ne sommes pas des musulmans": la réaction qui inquiète des membres de la communauté sikhe endeuillée|url=http://observers.france24.com/fr/content/20120807-nous-sommes-pas-musulmans-reaction-inquiete-membres-communaute-sikhe-endeuillee-oak-creek-temple-fusillade|accessdate=August 10, 2012|publisher=France 24|date=August 7, 2012}}</ref><ref name=HindustanTimes>{{cite news|title=Ex-girlfriend of gurdwara shooter arrested, faces weapon charge|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/NorthAmerica/Former-girlfriend-of-Gurdwara-shooter-to-face-weapon-charge/Article1-910132.aspx|accessdate=August 10, 2012|newspaper=Hindustan Times|date=August 8, 2012}}</ref><ref name=IndiaNYTimes>{{cite news|title=For Many Sikhs, Wisconsin Attack Has Troubling Echoes|url=http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/06/for-many-sikhs-wisconsin-attack-has-troubling-echoes/|accessdate=August 10, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 6, 2012}}</ref><ref name=DailyMail>{{cite news|last=Watson|first=Leon|title=Candles and prayers for the Sikh temple massacre victims as hundreds of people of all races gather to remember them |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2185303/Hundreds-turn-emotional-vigil-Wisconsin-remember-victims-Sikh-temple-massacre.html|accessdate=August 10, 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=August 8, 2012}}</ref> and the Boston Marathon Bombing.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clifton|first1=Allen|title=An Emotional Reaction to the Boston Marathon Bombing|url=http://www.forwardprogressives.com/bostonmarathon/|website=Forward Progressives|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref>
==History== Hall and Moline developed the idea for the Overpass Light Brigade through their personal reactions to the movement to recall Governor Walker. They originally used a single panel and string of [[Christmas lights]] to create an illuminated "Recall Walker" sign, which they carried at a local rally.<ref name=Maddow>{{cite web|last=Maddow|first=Rachel|title=Wreckoning|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4dsGYRR_jeI|website=The Rachel Maddow Show|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=August 10, 2012}}</ref> When images of the sign were circulated by [[mainstream media]] outlets including ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show (TV series)|The Rachel Maddow Show]]''<ref name="OnMilwaukee"/> and [[CNN]],<ref name=CNN>{{cite web|last=Welch|first=Chris|title=Crunch time for recall volunteers|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/03/politics/wisconsin-recall-bus-tour/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=August 10, 2012}}</ref> Hall and Moline decided to continue their efforts. Their next step was to create six individual signs that spelled "RECALL". After attempting to install the signs on the [[chainlink fence]] covering a pedestrian bridge across the [[Interstate 43|Interstate (I-43)]] and learning that doing so is illegal, Hall and Moline enlisted others to help carry the signs as a legal form of display. This participatory dimension to the work gives Overpass Light Brigade gatherings "the feel of a celebration, with scores of people gathering on the pedestrian overpasses," according to the ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]''.<ref name="Miner"/>
For the artists, their work with the Overpass Light Brigade is a "demonstration of citizen engagement... a Situationist paradigm of performativity within the contested and liminal zones of public space"<ref name="Building Movement">{{cite web|title=Overpass Light Brigade, the Law, and Building a Movement|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2012/05/19/1093036/-Overpass-Light-Brigade-the-Law-and-Building-a-Movement|website=Daily Kos|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> and a navigation of the tactics of visibility.<ref name="Bridge Parties">{{cite web|title=Wisconsin's Overpass Light Brigade and Drive by Seeing|url= http://www.dailykos.com/story/2012/03/31/1079614/-Wisconsin-s-Overpass-Light-Brigade-Bridge-Parties-and-Drive-by-Seeing|website=Daily Kos|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> They cite French [[Spectacle (critical theory)|critical theorist]] [[Guy Debord]]'s ''[[The Society of the Spectacle]]'' as an inspiration.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} Debord explored and explained how contemporary media creates spectacle that is essentially devoid of content. A founder of the artistic and political movement [[Situationist International]], he sought, through the construction of "situations," to create multiple strategies for reclaiming an individual's self-determination from the sedative effects of ubiquitous spectacle.<ref name="Mythic Tractors">{{cite web|title=Mythic Tractors March on Madison|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/03/13/955895/-Mythic-Tractors-March-On-Madison|website=Daily Kos|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref>
Hall and Moline had a history of making collaborative work, often about environmental issues and animal subjects, but rarely pushed beyond the boundaries of traditional art spaces.<ref name=Stern>{{cite web|last=Stern|first=Nathaniel|title=The Overpass Light Brigade: Art + Electronics in the Wisconsin Uprising|url=http://www.furtherfield.org/features/interviews/overpass-light-brigade-art-electronics-wisconsin-uprising|website=Furtherfield|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref> As a result of the Wisconsin protests, the artists became involved with activist work, in which the use of signs was pivotal. They also worked with other artists, activists, social scientists, and teachers to set up a short-lived [[political action committee]] called the Playground Legends, and began working in some of Milwaukee's African American communities on [[voter turnout|voter education]] and [[Get Out The Vote]] campaigns.<ref name="Bridge Parties"/> The group, with the central notion that [[public space]] and [[public discourse]] were necessary for functional democracy, set up "parties in the parks" for neighborhood groups, and used these relational activities to help create cohesion around a political purpose.<ref name="Summertime Manifesto">{{cite web|title=An Activist Manifesto or Hot Fun in the Summertime|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/06/25/988764/-An-Activist-Manifesto-or-Hot-Fun-In-the-Summertime|website=Daily Kos|accessdate=August 9, 2012}}</ref>
Brusky, a [[State school#United States|public school]] [[Teacher#United States|teacher]] and [[union organizer]], became an integral part of the OLB core after [[Streaming media|live-streaming]] focused actions. He is credited with expanding the greater OLB community through his relationships with national [[occupy movement|Occupy]] networks.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joe Brusky Joe Brusky Tactical Mediator Overpass Light Brigade|url=http://www.netrootsnation.org/profile/joe-brusky/|website=Netroots Nation|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref>
The OLB organization relies on a loose network of [[Volunteering|volunteers]] dedicated to "peaceful protest and artful activism."<ref>{{cite web|title=Overpass Light Brigade|url=http://overpasslightbrigade.org/|website=Overpass Light Brigade|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref>
==Growth== Affiliated Light Brigade organizations have been established in cities across the United States and internationally, and have organized to form the Light Brigade Network.<ref name="spark"/><ref name="facebook">{{cite web|title=Light Brigade Network|url=https://www.facebook.com/LightBrigadeNetwork|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}{{Primary source inline|date=July 2018}}</ref><ref name="troublenet">{{cite web|title=Overpass Light Brigade & the Light Brigade Network|url=http://beautifultrouble.org/practitioner/overpass-light-brigade-light-brigade-network/|website=Beautiful Trouble: A Toolbox for Revolution}}</ref> Hall emphasizes the importance for groups to consider how a collection of lighted letters can be recombined; to document the action through quality (night-time) photographs, videos, and blog posts; and to use social media to amplify the reach of the message.<ref name="troubleOLB">{{cite web|title=Light Brigade|url=http://beautifultrouble.org/tactic/light-brigade/|website=Beautiful Trouble|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref> The Light Brigade Network includes 46 chapters in cities in 21 US states, and six chapters in [[Croatia]], France, (Germany), [[New Zealand]], and the United Kingdom.<ref name="OLBnetwork">{{cite web|title=Overpass Light Brigade Network|url=http://overpasslightbrigade.org/network/|website=Overpass Light Brigade|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Zagreb Light Brigade|url=ps://www.facebook.com/zagreblightbrigade/|website=Facebook Community Page|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref>
==Light Brigade Network actions== Light Brigade groups organize actions around issues pertinent to their communities, and often collaborate on larger, national or international campaigns. Some noteworthy actions include:
* On April 10, 2014, the PEN American Center organized an event protesting China’s efforts to silence [[Ai Weiwei]] and other Chinese artists and writers. This event featured the NYC Light Brigade, holding lighted signs spelling "FREE EXPRESSION" in English and Chinese.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schumacher|first1=Mary Louise|title=Overpass Light Brigade, started in Milwaukee, part of free speech protest|url=http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/arts/ai-weiwei-addresses-china-at-brooklyn-museum-b99245816z1-254916451.html|accessdate=March 9, 2016|agency=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=April 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PEN American Center Defies Chinese Government, Brings Ai Weiwei to New York|url=http://www.pen.org/press-release/2014/04/11/pen-american-center-defies-chinese-government-brings-ai-weiwei-new-york|website=PEN America|publisher=PEN America|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref>
* On January 7, 2015 after the Charlie Hebdo terrorist attack, what has become the Paris Light Brigade brought lights spelling "NOT AFRAID" to a vigil in Paris.<ref>{{cite web|title=Not Afraid : "Ça nous paraissait important d'exprimer un message universel"|url=http://www.liberation.fr/societe/2015/01/08/not-afraid-ca-nous-paraissait-important-d-exprimer-un-message-universel_1176232|website=Liberation|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Charlie Hebdo attack vigils – in pictures|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2015/jan/07/charlie-hebdo-attack-vigils-in-pictures|accessdate=March 9, 2016|work=The Guardian|date=January 7, 2015}}</ref>
* Throughout December 2015, homes and businesses in the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn displayed signs as part of "Mi Casa Es No Su Casa: Illumination Against Gentrification.” This project was a collaboration between local activists, the Mayday Space and NYC Light Brigade.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fishbein|first1=Rebecca|title=Bushwick Woman Fights Gentrification With Christmas Lights: "Your Luxury Is Our Displacement"|url=http://gothamist.com/2015/12/29/bushwick_gentrification_lights.php|accessdate=March 9, 2016|publisher=Gothamist|date=December 29, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301163206/http://gothamist.com/2015/12/29/bushwick_gentrification_lights.php|archivedate=March 1, 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Activists in Bushwick Hope to Illuminate Gentrification|url=http://www.ny1.com/nyc/all-boroughs/news/2015/12/24/activists-in-bushwick-hope-to-illuminate-neighborhood-s-gentrification.html|accessdate=March 9, 2016|publisher=NY1 News|date=December 24, 2015}}</ref>
* The Chicago Light Brigade has been involved in numerous projects – on their own and in collaboration with other groups – to promote social justice for communities of color. They participated in the Week of Action Against Incarcerating Youth (May 2014) with the "Locked Up and Out" Rally, and protested the police shooting of Laquan McDonald in December 2015 with the "Memorial Blockade" in downtown Chicago.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chicago Protest Against Cop-Involved Shooting Blocks Traffic|url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/Chicago-Protest-Against-Cop-Involved-Shooting-Blocks-Traffic-362576521.html|accessdate=March 9, 2016|agency=NBC Chicago|publisher=NBCUniversal Media, LLC|date=December 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hayes|first1=Kelly|title=Memorial Blockade: A Love Letter to Communities Resisting Police Violence|url=http://www.truth-out.org/opinion/item/34144-memorial-blockade-a-love-letter-to-communities-resisting-police-violence|website=Truthout|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref>
== Films== The spectacle and "mediagenic quality" of OLB's actions have made it the subject of several film projects. ''Overpass Light Brigade'', a short documentary by filmmakers Matt Mullans and Dusan Harminc, was released in 2013 and was screened in over 25 venues, including Woods Hole Film Festival, Marfa Film Festival, and the PBS Online Film Festival.<ref name="Forward Press Release"/><ref name="imdb">{{cite web|title=Overpass Light Brigade (2014)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2766000/|publisher=IMDb|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Overpass Light Brigade Screenings|url=http://www.olbfilm.com/screenings.html|website=Overpass Light Brigade The Film|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Overpass Light Brigade, short film by makers of Forward, shows in PBS Online Film Festival|url=http://urbanmilwaukee.com/pressrelease/overpass-light-brigade-short-film-by-makers-of-forward-shows-in-pbs-online-film-festival/|accessdate=March 9, 2016|publisher=Urban Milwaukee|date=June 27, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2014 PBS Online Film Festival|url=https://www.pbs.org/filmfestival/2014/|website=''pbs.org''|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref>
Also in 2013, [[Planned Parenthood]], with 371 Productions and documentary filmmaker [[Brad Lichtenstein]], created the "Be Visible" campaign, with a video highlighting women's stories and featuring the Overpass Light Brigade.<ref>{{cite web|title=Be Visible|url=https://vimeo.com/76162098|via=Vimeo|publisher=Planned Parenthood Saves Lives|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Be Visible|url=http://overpasslightbrigade.org/visible/|website=Overpass Light Brigade Blog|publisher=OLB|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref><ref name="371Productions">{{cite web|title=371 Productions About Us|url=http://371productions.com/about-us/|website=371 Productions|publisher=371 Productions|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref>

'''Oxidizable carbon ratio dating''' is a method of [[Chronological dating|dating]] in [[archaeology]] and [[earth science]] that can be used to derive or estimate the age of soil and sediment samples up to 35,000 years old. The method is experimental, and it is not as widely used in [[archaeology]] as other [[chronometric]] methods such as [[radiocarbon dating]].
The methodology was introduced by Archaeology Consulting Team from [[Essex Junction]] in 1992.<ref name="Frink, Douglas S. 1992">Frink, Douglas S. (1992) The Chemical Variability of Carbonized Organic Matter Through Time. ''Archaeology of Eastern North America'' 20: 67-79.</ref><ref>Frink, Douglas S. (1994) The Oxidizable Carbon Ratio (OCR): A Proposed Solution to Some of the Problems Encountered with Radiocarbon Data. ''North American Archaeologist'' 15(1): 17-29 [http://baywood.metapress.com/openurl.asp?genre=article&issn=0197-6931&volume=15&issue=1]</ref><ref>Frink, Douglas S. (1995) Application of the Oxidizable Carbon Ratio (OCR) Dating Procedure and its Implications for Pedogenic Research. In ''Pedological Perspectives in Archaeological Research''. SSA Special Publication 44. Soil Science Society of America: Madison, WI.</ref>
== Process == This dating method works by measuring the ratio of oxidizable carbon to organic carbon. If the sample is freshly burned there will be no oxidizable carbon because it would have all been removed by the combustion process. Over time this will change and the amount of organic carbon will decrease to be replaced by oxidizable carbon. By measuring the ratio of oxidized carbon to organic carbon (the OCR) and applying it to the following equation the age of the sample can be determined with a very low [[standard error (statistics)|standard error]].<ref name="Frink">Douglas S. Frink. [http://www.eprida.com/hydro/ecoss/background/applicationofocr.pdf "Application of the Oxidizable Carbon Ratio (OCR) Dating Procedure and its Implications for Pedogenic Research".] Accessed November 2, 200.</ref>
:<math>\text{OCR}_\text{DATE} = \frac{\text{OCR} \times \text{Depth} \times \text{Mean temperature} \times \text{Mean rainfall}}{\text{Mean texture} \times \sqrt\text{pH}\times\sqrt{\%C}\times 14.4888}</math>
==Evaluations and applications of the method== It is important to note that the OCR dating method is, like any scientific procedure, subject to testing, evaluation, and refinement.
The Oxidizable Carbon Ratio method was the subject of a Point–CounterPoint feature of the Society for American Archaeology Bulletin in 1999.<ref>D. J. Killick, A. J. T. Jull, and G. S Burr [http://www.saa.org/Publications/saabulletin/17-5/saa18.html "A Failure to Discriminate: Querying Oxidizable Carbon Ratio (OCR) Dating" and "The Scientific Basis of Oxidizable Carbon Ratio (OCR) Dating"] Accessed December 8th, 2007</ref> In that article, Killick, Jull, and Burr suggest that the OCR method has (1) never been described in a peer-reviewed journal article, (2) that no "scientifically acceptable" demonstration of the accuracy and precision of OCR dating has been published, and (3) that the equation underlying the OCR method is questionable because of site-specific environmental factors. Frink's rejoinder to these comments points out that (1) the OCR method has indeed been described in a peer-reviewed journal article,<ref name="Frink, Douglas S. 1992"/> (2) that the accuracy and precision of the method have been reported in multiple venues and that the concept of "scientifically acceptable" is context- and person-specific (and therefore a red herring), and that (3) the equation underlying the OCR method takes into account the seven factors of soil formation, and that these factors are routinely used in soil science applications without question. In the end, Frink concludes that the OCR method—like any scientific advance—warrants further study, and he points out that even the now venerable "scientifically acceptable" method of radiocarbon dating was much maligned when it was first introduced.
Frink and others have published multiple studies demonstrating that OCR dates can correlate well with [[radiocarbon date]]s (see list of published references provided below). Fullen's study of the Sarah Peralta site in Louisiana <ref>Stephen R. Fullen (1998). [http://etd.lsu.edu/docs/available/etd-11162005-133233/unrestricted/Fullen_thesis.pdf Temporal Trends in Tchula Period Pottery in Louisiana]. Pages 63-65. Accessed December 27, 2007.</ref> found that the OCR method served as an effective means of inferring time at the site in the absence of radiometrically dateable charcoal. He concludes that whereas debate remains concerning the OCR procedure, "the well-corroborated dates that the LSU Museum of Natural Science has had returned on material processed with OCR and conventional radiocarbon dating...the dates returned on material from Zone 3 will be considered accurate until such time that OCR dating is proven invalid." (''ibid''. p. 65)
The OCR method has been used in a large number of archaeological and geomorphological studies, and an incomplete list of published references is provided below. It has been used to evaluate soil development in a range of temperature regimes including arid,<ref name="Harrison, Rodney 2000">Harrison, Rodney, and Frink, Douglas S. (2000) The OCR Carbon Dating Procedure in Australia: New Dates from Wilinyjibari Rockshelter, Southeast Kimberley, Western Australia. ''Australian Archaeology'' 51:6-15</ref><ref name="Frink, Douglas S 2001">Frink, Douglas S. and Ronald I. Dorn (2001) Beyond Taphonomy: Pedogenic Transformations of the Archaeological Record in Monumental Earthworks. ''Journal of the Arizona-Nevada Academy of Science'' 33(3): 182-202</ref> semi-arid ,<ref>Nami, Hugo, and Frink, Douglas S. (1999) Cronologia Obtenida por la Tasa del Carbono Organico Oxidable (OCR) en Markatch Aike 1 (Cuenca del Rio Chico, Santa Cruz). ''Anales del Instituo de la Patagonia'' 27:231-237</ref> thermic,<ref>Perttula, Timothy K. (1997) A Compendium of Radiocarbon and Oxidizable Carbon Ratio Dates from Archaeological Sites in East Texas, with a Discussion of the Age and Dating of Select Components and Phases. ''Radiocarbon'' 39(3): 305-342</ref><ref>Frink, Douglas S. and Timothy K. Perttula (2001) Analysis of the 39 Oxidizable Carbon Ratio Dates from Mound A, Mound B, and the Village Area at the Calvin Davis or Morse Mounds Site (41SY27). ''North American Archaeologist'' 22(2): 143-160</ref> mesic,<ref>[http://www.comp-archaeology.org/OCR_first.htm Frink, Douglas S. (1998) The First OCR Dates from the Czech Republic]</ref> and frigic. It has also been applied to a variety of landforms including stratified fluvial deposits,<ref name="Harrison, Rodney 2000"/><ref>Webb, Paul A., and David S. Leigh (1995) Geomorphological and Archaeological Investigations of a Buried Site on the Yadkin River Floodplain. ''Southern Indian Studies'' 44:1-36</ref> desert pavements and vessicular soils,<ref name="Frink, Douglas S 2001"/><ref name="Dorn, Ronald I. 2001">Dorn, Ronald I., Edward Stasack, Diane Stasack, and Persis Clarkson (2001) Analyzing Petroglyphs and Geoglyphs with Four New Perspectives: Evaluating What's There and What's Not. ''American Indian Rock Art'' 27: 77-96.</ref> and glacial deposits. Analyses also include monumental earthworks<ref name="Frink, Douglas S 2001"/><ref>Saunders, Joe W., [[Rolfe D. Mandel]], Roger T. Saucier, E. Thurman Allen, C.T. Hallmark, Jay K. Johnson, Edwin H. Jackson, Charles M. Allen, Gary L. Stringer, Douglas S. Frink, James K. Feathers, Stephen Williams, [[Kristen Gremillion|Kristen J. Gremillion]], Malcolm F. Vidrine, and Reca Jones (1997) A Mound Complex in Louisiana at 5400-5000 Years Before Present. ''Science'' 277:1796-1799</ref><ref>Wesler, Kit (1997) The Wickliffe Mounds Project: Implications for Late Mississippi Period Chronology, Settlement and Mortuary Patterns in Western Kentucky. ''Proceedings of the Prehistoric Society'' 63:261-283</ref><ref>Wesler, Kit (2001) ''Excavations at Wickliffe Mounds''. The University of Alabama Press, Tuscaloosa</ref> and geoglyphs.<ref name="Dorn, Ronald I. 2001"/><ref>Dorn, Ronald (2004) Experimental Approaches to Dating Petroglyphs and Geoglyphs with Rock Varnish in the California Deserts: Current Status and Future Directions. In ''The Human Journey and Ancient Life in California's Deserts'', M. W. Allen and J. Reed (eds). Maturango Museum Publication 15. pp. 211-224. Maturango Museum: Ridgecrest, CA. Available on-line [http://alliance.la.asu.edu/dorn/Millennium2004.pdf]</ref>

{{lead missing|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox scientist |name =Pierre Pica |image =Pierre Pica 2006.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date|1951|01|5|}} |birth_place =[[Nice]], [[France]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |citizenship =[[France|French]] |nationality = |ethnicity = |field = |work_institutions = [[CNRS]] |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = [[Noam Chomsky]] |influenced = |prizes = |footnotes = |signature = |spouse= }} '''Pierre Pica''' (born January 5, 1951), is a research associate (Chargé de Recherche) at the National Center for Scientific Research in [[Paris]]. Associated Professor with the Brain Institute of the [[Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte]], he is a specialist in [[theoretical linguistics]] and more specifically of comparative [[syntax]].
Dr. Pica has concentrated his research on the notion of parameters in linguistic. He has also shown that the respective properties of reflexive pronouns could be derived from their morphological properties. He is currently studying the distinction between the internal and external aspects of the Faculty of language and is also working on a fine grained distinction between [[Linguistic competence|competence]] and [[linguistic performance]].
Over the last twenty years, Pica has risen to prominence as a result of his work on [[Binding Theory]] <ref>Pierre Pica, (1987), "On the Nature of the Reflexivization Cycle", Proceedings of the North Eastern Linguistic Society 17, 2 (1987) 483-500</ref> and [[evidentiality]]. More recently he has been working on [[Mundurucu]] (an indigenous language spoken in Para (Brazil). He is currently collaborating with [[Stanislas Dehaene]] and [[Elizabeth Spelke]] in a study of numerical expressions and enumeration in [[Mundurucu]]. This research stresses the importance of these data for the study of the interaction of the Language Faculty and restricted set of pre-verbal 'core knowledge'. This research which stresses the importance of the notion of culture gap, as defined by [[Kenneth Hale]] (1975)'s seminal work,<ref>Kenneth L. Hale, (1975), "Gaps in grammar and Culture", in M. Dake Kinkade, Kenneth Hale & [[Oswald Werner]] eds. Linguistic & Anthropology : In honor of C.F. Voegelin, 1975, p. 295-315</ref> stands in opposition to the hypothesis related to [[relativism]] as derived from [[Edward Sapir|Sapir]] and [[Benjamin Lee Whorf|Whorf]] in that it tends to demonstrate that knowledge, even culture, can in part be reduced to a small set of universal principles and intuitions. The research has given rise to a series of publications in [[Science (journal)|Science magazine]].<ref>Pica, P, C Lemer, V Izard & Dehaene, S. (2004), "Exact and approximate arithmetic in an Amazonian Indigene Group" Science, 306, pp. 499–503</ref>

{{Infobox academic |name = Richard W. Lariviere |image= Richard_Lariviere.jpg |birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], [[Illinois]], US |nationality= [[United States]] |workplaces = [[University of Texas at Austin]] (1982–2006)
[[University of Kansas]] (2006–2009)
[[University of Oregon]] (2009–2011)
[[Field Museum]] (2012–) |alma_mater = [[University of Iowa]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]]) (1972)
[[University of Pennsylvania]] ([[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD.]]) (1978) |spouse = Janis Worcester (1984–present) }} '''Richard W. Lariviere''' is the president of the [[Field Museum]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. He took over the post on October 1, 2012.{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Steve|title=Vote makes Richard Lariviere's appointment as Field Museum head official|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/chi-richard-lariviere-field-museum-head-20120417,0,3896476.column|publisher=The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=18 April 2012}} Previously, he served as the President of the [[University of Oregon]] from July 2009 until November 2011. ==Early life and education== Lariviere was born in [[Chicago]] and grew up in [[Marshalltown, Iowa]]. He earned a B.A. in [[History of Religion]] from the [[University of Iowa]] in 1972, where he was a member of [[Phi Beta Kappa]]. In 1978, he earned his [[Doctorate]] in [[Sanskrit]] from the [[University of Pennsylvania]]. After spending time in India, Lariviere built an impressive academic career around the country’s languages, histories, religions and culture. He has published articles and several books on Indian legal history. He reads eight languages and speaks French and Hindi. He has conducted research in London, Oxford, Calcutta, Poona, Kathmandu, Tokyo, Beijing, Lahore, Munich, Colombo and Madras, and many smaller cities.[http://fieldmuseum.org/users/richard-lariviere Our Staff], The Field Museum ==Career== Prior to serving as the president and CEO of Field Museum, Lariviere was the President of the University of Oregon (UO) from July 1, 2009 through November 2011. During his tenure there, he cultivated the University's growing reputation for innovation in the classroom and in research, sharpening the University's focus on sustainability and international partnerships. Before arriving at Oregon, Lariviere was Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost at the [[University of Kansas]] from 2006 to 2009, and Dean of the College of Liberal Arts at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] from 1999 to 2006. Lariviere also served as the inaugural Associate Vice President for International Programs at UT Austin. Additionally, Lariviere has had a successful career as a consultant for American and Indian companies in information technology and business process outsourcing. He also served on corporate boards in the IT industry in Europe and India. ==Recognitions and awards== Lariviere is a Fellow of the Institute for Innovation, Creativity & Capital in Austin ([[IC² Institute]]), a life Member of the Council on Foreign Relations, a Fellow of the Royal Asiatic Society of Great Britain, a life Member of the American Oriental Society, and a Founding Member of the Society for Design and Process Science. He has earned several awards for outstanding contributions, including the Margaret C. Berry Award in 2004 and the Eyes of Texas Award in 2004 and 1993. He was selected by the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences|Royal Dutch Academy]] to give the annual [[Jan Gonda|Gonda]] Lecture in 1994, and the [[Collège de France]] honored him with the status of Professeur ƒtranger in 1996. In 1989, his book on Indian legal procedure was selected as the best book of the year on South Asia by the CESMEO Institute in Torino, Italy. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://fieldmuseum.org/users/richard-lariviere Field Museum's President] *{{official website|http://lariviere.uoregon.edu/}} {{s-start}} {{s-aca}} {{succession box | before=[[David B. Frohnmayer|Dave Frohnmayer]] | title=[[List of University of Oregon faculty and staff#Presidents of the University of Oregon|President of the University of Oregon]] | after=[[Robert M. Berdahl]]
Interim | years= 2009–2011 }} {{s-end}} {{University of Oregon presidents}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lariviere, Richard W.}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Presidents of the University of Oregon]] [[Category:University of Oregon people]] [[Category:University of Oregon faculty]] [[Category:University of Texas at Austin faculty]] [[Category:University of Kansas faculty]] [[Category:University of Iowa alumni]] [[Category:University of Pennsylvania alumni]] [[Category:Religious studies scholars]] [[Category:American Sanskrit scholars]]

[[File:NMBSevenSagesMosaicBaalbekRectified.jpg|thumb|350px|<center>Mosaïc of the Seven Sages, [[Baalbeck]], 3rd century A.D., [[National Museum of Beirut]]. [[Calliope]] at the center, and clockwise from top: [[Socrates]], [[Chilon]], [[Pittacus]], [[Periander]], [[Cleobulus]] (damaged section), [[Bias of Priene|Bias]], [[Thales]], and [[Solon]].</center>]] The '''Seven Sages''' ('''of Greece''') or '''Seven Wise Men''' ([[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: {{lang|grc|οἱ ἑπτὰ σοφοί}} ''hoi hepta sophoi'') was the title given by [[classical Greece|classical Greek]] tradition to seven [[philosopher]]s, statesmen, and law-givers of the [[6th century BC]] who were renowned for their [[Sophia (wisdom)|wisdom]].
==The Seven Sages== The list of seven sages includes: * [[Thales|Thales of Miletus]] ({{circa}} 624 – {{circa}} 546 BC) is the first well-known philosopher, mathematician, and astronomer. His advice, "[[Know thyself]]," was engraved on the front [[facade]] of the [[Oracle of Apollo|Temple of Apollo]] in [[Delphi]]. * [[Pittacus of Mytilene]] ({{circa}} 640 – 568 BC) governed [[Mytilene]] ([[Lesbos]]). He tried to reduce the power of the nobility and was able to govern with the support of the [[wikt:demos#Noun 2|demos]], whom he favoured. * [[Bias of Priene]] (fl. 6th century BC) was a politician and legislator of the 6th century BC. * [[Solon|Solon of Athens]] ({{circa}} 638 – 558 BC) was a famous legislator and reformer from [[Athens]], framing the laws that shaped the [[Athenian democracy]]. * the fifth and sixth sage are variously given as two of: [[Cleobulus]], tyrant of [[Lindos]] (fl. {{circa}} 600 BC), reported as either the grandfather or father-in-law of Thales; [[Periander|Periander of Corinth]] (b. before 634 BC, d. {{circa}} 585 BC); [[Myson of Chenae]] (6th century BC); [[Anacharsis|Anacharsis the Scythian]] (6th century BC). * [[Chilon of Sparta]] (fl. 555 BC) was a [[Sparta]]n politician to whom the militarization of Spartan society was attributed.
== Sources and legends == [[File:Seven_Sages_of_Greece.jpg|thumb|right|Earliest passage in which the Seven Wise Men are mentioned together, from [[Oxyrhynchus Papyri]].]] The oldest<ref>A. Griffiths, "Seven Sages", in ''[[Oxford Classical Dictionary]]'' (3rd ed.). All the sources are collected in Bruno Snell, ''Leben und Meinungen der Sieben Weisen. Griechische und lateinische Quellen erläutert und übertragen.'' Munich, 1971.</ref> explicit mention on record of a standard list of seven sages is in [[Plato]]'s [[Protagoras (dialogue)|''Protagoras'']], where [[Socrates]] says: {{quote|...There some, both at present and of old, who recognized that [[Sparta]]nizing is much more a love of wisdom than a love of physical exercise, knowing that the ability to utter such [brief and terse] remarks belongs to a perfectly educated man. Among these were [[Thales of Miletus]], and [[Pittacus of Mytilene]], and [[Bias of Priene]], and our own [[Solon]], and [[Cleobulus]] of Lindus, and [[Myson of Chenae]], and the seventh of them was said to be [[Chilon of Sparta]]. They all emulated and admired and were students of Spartan education, could tell their wisdom was of this sort by the brief but memorable remarks they each uttered when they met and jointly the first fruits of their wisdom to Apollo in his shrine at [[Delphi]], writing what is on every man's lips: ''Know thyself'', and ''Nothing too much''. Why do I say this? Because this was the manner of philosophy among the ancients, a kind of [[laconic]] brevity.<ref>''Protagoras'' 342e–343b, trans. R.E. Allen.</ref>}}
The section of the Protagoras in which appears this passage is "elaborately ironical", making it unclear which of its parts may be taken seriously,<ref>p. 156, [[James Adam (classicist)|James Adam]], ''Platonis Protagoras'', Cambridge University Press, 1893; p. 83, C.C.W. Taylor, ''Plato: Protagoras'', Oxford University Press, 2002. The words "elaborately ironical" are Adam's.</ref> although [[Diogenes Laertius]] later confirms that there were indeed seven such individuals who were held in high esteem for their wisdom well before Plato's time. According to [[Demetrius Phalereus]], it was during the [[Archon of Athens|archonship]] of Damasias (582/1 BC) that the seven first become known as "the wise men", Thales being the first so acknowledged.<ref>[[Geoffrey Kirk|Kirk]], Raven, & Schofield, ''The Presocratic Philosophers'' (Cambridge, 1983, 2nd edition), p. 76, citing Diogenes Laertius, i. 22.</ref>
[[Image:Nuremberg chronicles f 60v 1.png|right|thumb|The Seven Sages, depicted in the ''[[Nuremberg Chronicle]]'']] Diogenes points out, however, that there was among his sources great disagreement over which figures should be counted among the seven.<ref name="laertius141">Diogenes Laertius, i. 41</ref> Perhaps the two most common substitutions were to exchange [[Periander]] or [[Anacharsis]] for Myson. On Diogenes' first list of seven, which he introduces with the words "These men are acknowledged wise," [[Periander]] appears instead of [[Myson]];<ref name="laertius113">Diogenes Laertius, i. 13</ref> the same substitution appears in ''The Masque of the Seven Sages'' by [[Ausonius]].<ref>Ausonius, [https://archive.org/stream/deciausonius01ausouoft#page/310/mode/2up ''The Masque of the Seven Sages'']</ref> Both [[Ephorus]]<ref name="laertius141"/> and [[Plutarch]] (in his ''Banquet of the Seven Sages'') substituted Anacharsis for Myson. Diogenes Laertius further states that [[Dicaearchus]] gave ten possible names,<ref name="laertius141"/> [[Hippobotus]] suggested twelve names,<ref name="laertius142">Diogenes Laertius, i. 42</ref> and [[Hermippus of Smyrna|Hermippus]] enumerated seventeen possible sages from which different people made different selections of seven.<ref name="laertius142"/> Leslie Kurke contends that "[[Aesop]] was a popular contender for inclusion in the group"; an epigram of the 6th century AD poet [[Agathias]] (''Palatine Anthology'' 16.332) refers to a statue of the Seven Sages, with Aesop standing before them.<ref>Leslie Kurke, ''Aesopic Conversations: Popular Tradition, Cultural Dialogue, and the Invention of Greek Prose'', Princeton University Press, 2010, pp. 131–2, 135.</ref>
Later tradition ascribed to each sage a pithy saying of his own, but ancient as well as modern scholars have doubted the legitimacy of such ascriptions.<ref>H. Parke and D. Wormell, ''The Delphic Oracle'', (Basil Blackwell, 1956), vol. 1, pp. 387–389.</ref> A compilation of 147 maxims, inscribed at Delphi, was preserved by the fifth century AD scholar [[Stobaeus]] as "Sayings of the Seven Sages,"<ref>Kurke, p. 109.</ref> but "the actual authorship of the...maxims set up on the Delphian temple may be left uncertain. Most likely they were popular proverbs, which tended later to be attributed to particular sages."<ref>Parke & Wormell, p. 389.</ref>
In addition to being credited for pithy sayings, the wise men were also apparently famed for practical inventions; in Plato's [[The Republic (Plato)|''Republic'']] (600a), it is said that it "befits a wise man" to have "many inventions and useful devices in the crafts or sciences" attributed to him, citing Thales and [[Anacharsis]] the [[Scythia]]n as examples.
According to a number of moralistic stories, there was a golden tripod (or, in some versions of the story, a bowl or cup) which was to be given to the wisest. Allegedly, it passed in turn from one of the seven sages to another, beginning with Thales, until one of them (either Thales or Solon, depending on the story) finally dedicated it to [[Apollo]] who was held to be wisest of all.<ref>Diogenes Laertius i. 27ff.; R. Martin, "Seven Sages", ''Encyclopedia of Classical Philosophy'' (ed. D. Zeyl, 1997), p. 487; Parke & Wormell, pp. 387–388</ref>
According to Diogenes, [[Dicaearchus]] claimed that the seven "were neither wise men nor philosophers, but merely shrewd men, who had studied legislation."<ref>Diogenes Laertius, i. 40.</ref> And according to at least one modern scholar, the claim is correct: "With the exception of Thales, no one whose life is contained in [Diogenes'] Book I [i.e. none of the above] has any claim to be styled a philosopher."<ref>p. 42 note a, R. Hicks, ''Diogenes Laertius: Lives of Eminent Philosophers'', vol. 1, Harvard University Press, 1925.</ref>
==See also== * [[Sage (sophos)]] * [[Saptarishi]] * [[Seven Sages of the Bamboo Grove]] * [[Seven Wise Masters]]

{{Infobox collection | name = Southam's Cardall Collection | image = | image_caption = | housed_at = [[Southam]], [[Warwickshire]], [[England]] | curators = Friends of the Cardall Collection | funded_by = | website = }}
'''Southam's Cardall Collection''' contains [[Cultural artifact|artefacts]], [[document]]s, and [[photograph]]s relating to the history of the town of [[Southam]], [[Warwickshire]], [[England]], including its people, and the surrounding villages.<ref name=Friends>{{cite book| author=Cardall Collection | title=A Heritage Centre for Southam | year=2010 | publisher=Friends of the Cardall Collection | location=UK }}</ref>
Since 2006, the Collection has been managed by a team of volunteers, '''The Friends of the Cardall Collection'''.<ref>{{cite web| last=Cadogan | first=Bernard | title=Community Archives | url=http://www.communityarchives.org.uk/page_id__947_path__0p2p12p35p.aspx | accessdate=15 March 2012}}</ref> However, the collection is at risk because it does not have a suitable, permanent home. The Friends of the Cardall Collection's primary aim is to establish a permanent home for the collection within Southam town centre, to enable it to be used for the benefit of the wider community. Members of the Friends are interested in the history of Southam and its surrounding villages.<ref name=Friends />
==Background== The collection was started by the late Jack Cardall, and his widow, Rene, continued this work until her death in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.leamingtoncourier.co.uk/news/local/last_call_before_collection_is_sold_1_1057025 | title=Last call before collection is sold|newspaper=The Courier, [[Leamington Spa]] | date=26 February 2008}}</ref> It contains in excess of 4,500 items. In addition, there is a photographic [[archive]], largely donated by a local historian, that contains over 1,500 negatives and slides, and 450 unique glass negatives taken by an amateur photographer in the early days of the 20th century.<ref name=Friends />
Southam is a historic market town in Warwickshire, England, and has many unique and ancient buildings.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Megalithic Portal | url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=18421|accessdate=15 March 2012}}</ref> Located on major north/south and east/west routes, it was for many years a bustling transport and trading hub, particularly in the era before railways.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
==Current projects== The Friends' current projects include:<ref name=Friends />
===Documenting the collection=== *Identifying, recording and describing all items *Creating a computer database of items *Scanning all documents *Photographing all objects *Digitising all photographic material
===Outreach activities=== *Working with local schools and colleges *Working with retirement homes and similar organisations *Walk & Talk events *Presentations for local groups *Exhibitions and displays *Partnership with Southam Fire Service and Southam Primary Schools
===Oral history=== *Digitally recording information and memories of local people *Creation and sale of oral history CDs
==Other recent activities== *Helping with a television documentary about one of Southam’s historic buildings. *Introducing Exchange Students to the town. *Taking part in local community events *Dealing with enquiries about local history *Partnership working with local artists<ref>{{cite web|last=Hughes|first=Ryan|title=Artist in Residency's blog|url=http://www.a-n.co.uk/artists_talking/projects/single/1554929|accessdate=17 March 2012}}</ref> and historians
==Future plans== *To expand the Collection *To widen access to the Collection *To encourage the involvement of younger people using the internet and social media *To assist schools with their local history study *To raise awareness and engage local people with Southam’s historic past *To make the Collection work for Southam in terms of increased tourism and trade<ref>{{cite web|title=Southam First|url=http://southamfirst.org/sub-groups/community-and-culture/|accessdate=15 March 2012}}</ref>
==Funding and support== The Friends of Southam's Cardall Collection receives support from the Warwickshire Community Museum’s Officer, including advice, training and information about funding opportunities.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} The work of the Friends is funded by donations, membership subscriptions, sales of small items, and small grants from awarding bodies. The Group has had some success with applications for small grants for specific projects. Computer equipment, scanners, lighting equipment, projectors, etc. have been acquired to support community work and to carry out the conservation work that underpins the group's activities. However, to pay for running costs (rent, rates, electricity, water,) volunteers also have to concentrate on revenue earning projects.<ref name=Friends />
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox film | name = The Yankles | image = The_Yankles.jpg | caption = Theatrical poster | director = David R. Brooks | producer = David R. Brooks
Michael Morhaime | writer = David R. Brooks
Zev Brooks | starring = [[Brian Wimmer]]
Michael Buster
Susanne Sutchy | music = Eddie Hernandez | cinematography = Boris Price | editing = Lance Chapman | studio = | distributor = Magnolia Pictures | released = {{Film date|2009|11|15|Bel-Air Film Festival}} | runtime = 115 minutes | language = English | country = United States | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Yankles''''' is a 2009 film directed by David R. Brooks, about a fictitious college-level baseball team made up of students from an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] [[Yeshiva]]. Filmed in Utah with a "predominantly [[Mormon]] cast," the film was shown at a number of film festivals, winning a number of festival awards, although it was never theatrically released.[http://www.the-numbers.com/interactive/newsStory.php?newsID=7328 www.the-numbers.com, retrieved August 14, 2012] However, in 2012 it was picked up by [[Magnolia Pictures|Magnolia Home Entertainment]] for DVD release.[http://articles.hbindependent.com/2012-06-06/entertainment/tn-hbi-0607-yankles-20120606_1_baseball-team-independent-film-anaheim-international-film-festival/2 Stockdale, Jenny, Huntington Beach Independent, June 6, 2012] ==Plot and title== The [[Rosh yeshiva]] ([[rabbi]]nical dean) of an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] [[yeshiva]] (theological school) decides that the school should have a baseball team to compete in the college league. Elliot (Michael Buster), one of the students with a background in minor league baseball, is able to convince Charlie Jones (Brian Wimmer), a former major league player who had been imprisoned as a result of DUI convictions—and now has to perform almost 200 hours of community service—to coach the team. As he coaches the team, he gives the players "a new measure of skill and confidence," as they help him regain his self-respect.[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_yankles_2011/ Rottentomatoes.com] The title is the name of the ball team, based on Yankle as the [[Yiddish language]] nickname for Jacob, used as a play-on-words with the famous ball team, the [[New York Yankees|Yankees]].[http://emol.org/film/archives/heartlandfilmfestival/2010/yankles.html Ritrosky, Madelyn, Film Entertainment Magazine, retrieved August 14, 2012] An additional pun is reflected in the words painted on the school bus the yeshiva ball team uses: "In the Big Inning." ==Themes== According to publicity releases, the film is "not just a funny film about baseball; it's about second chances, reconciliation and forgiveness....about making mistakes and moving on, about living by principles and not passions."[http://articles.hbindependent.com/2012-01-04/entertainment/tn-hbi-0105-yankles-20120104_1_independent-film-newport-beach-film-festival-screening Vittachi, Imran, "Film with local ties to screen at Bella Terra," Huntington Beach Independent, January 4, 2012] ==Production== Co-writers (and brothers) David and Zev Brooks have stated that the idea for the movie came to them when they were discussing movie concepts at their dinner table and the film ''[[The Chosen (1981 film)|The Chosen]]'' brought to mind a movie scene with Orthodox and non-Orthodox students playing baseball.[http://gotriad.news-record.com/content/2011/02/23/article/the_yankles Milan, Alexa, "The Yankles," Feb. 24, 2011, gotriad.com]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} They agreed the image was "visually entertaining" and built the film around that image. Once the script was completed, the brothers established "DZB productions" and began seeking out investors to fund the film. When it became clear that shooting a low-budget independent film in Los Angeles would be too expensive for them, they made the decision to film the movie in Utah, using many local men and women for cast and crew. According to the film's creators, the decision to film in Utah was made based on a combination of economic factors, the cooperation they would receive from the Utah Film Commission, and the large number of actors and film crew members who lived in that State.[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705376594/The-Yankles-featured-at-LDS-Jewish-film-festivals.html?pg=all Hardy, Rodger L., "'The Yankles' featured at LDS, Jewish Film Festivals," Deseret News, January 26, 2010, retrieved August 14, 2010] Evidently because of the large number of Mormon actors and crew members involved in the production, the film (featured in many Jewish film festivals) was included in the "LDS Film Festival" as well. While the brothers co-wrote the film, David directed it and Zev produced it. The movie was filmed on a tight schedule, and because the actors were not trained baseball players—and there was no time on the schedule to hold a training camp to improve their skills—the number of actual scenes of ball games were limited. The script was completed by the two brothers in 1996, and most of the film was completed by 2007, but a post-production lack of funding postponed the film's completion until 2009. ===DVD extras=== The DVD includes an 11-minute behind-the-scenes film, 11 minutes of extended musical numbers, and 16 minutes of deleted scenes. ==Cast== The cast includes:[http://www.yankles.com/cast.html Cast page, movie home page] *[[Brian Wimmer]] (Charlie) *Michael Buster (Elliot) *Susanne Sutchy (Deborah) *[[Don Most]] (Frankie) *[[Bart Johnson]] (Sledge) Brian Wimmer and Susanne Sutchy, two of the main stars of the movie, are married in real life. ==Awards== {{primary sources|section|date=September 2012}} The awards this film has received include:[http://www.yankles.com/movie.html Movie homepage] *Golden Ace Award, Las Vegas Film Festival, 2010 *Best Comedy, International Family Film Festival, 2010 *Audience Choice: Best Feature, [[Palm Beach International Film Festival]], 2010 *Audience Award: Best Feature, Los Angeles Jewish Film Festival, 2010 *Audience Choice: Best Feature, Anaheim International Film Festival, 2010 *Best Director (David R. '''Theological aesthetics''' is the interdisciplinary study of [[theology]] and [[aesthetics]], and has been defined as being "concerned with questions about [[God]] and issues in theology in the light of and perceived through sense knowledge ([[wikt:sensation|sensation]], [[feeling]], [[imagination]]), through [[beauty]], and [[the arts]]".<ref name="Thiessen">{{cite_book | author=Gesa Elsbeth Thiessen | title=Theological Aesthetics: A Reader | publisher=Eerdmans | year=2004 | isbn=0-8028-2888-4 | page=1}}</ref> This field of study is broad and includes not only a theology of beauty, but also the dialogue between '''theology and the arts''', such as [[dance]], [[drama]], [[film]], [[literature]], [[music]], [[poetry]], and the [[visual arts]].
Notable theologians and philosophers that have dealt with this subject include [[Augustine of Hippo]], [[Thomas Aquinas]], [[Martin Luther]], [[Jonathan Edwards (theologian)|Jonathan Edwards]], [[Søren Kierkegaard]], [[Karl Barth]], and [[Hans Urs von Balthasar]], among others.
Theological aesthetics has recently seen rapid growth as a subject for discussions, publications, and advanced academic studies.
==Aesthetics in Christian theology==
===The early church=== Theological writings during the period of the early Christian church which deal with aesthetics span from circa 160 to c. 650 and include writings by [[Justin Martyr]], [[Irenaeus]], [[Origen]], [[Augustine of Hippo]], [[Pseudo-Dionysius]], and [[Maximus the Confessor]], among others. Prevalent themes during this period included "the [[Divinization (Christian)|vision of God]] or of God's glory, the image of God in Christ and in us, and the concern with idol worship".<ref name="Thiessen9">Thiessen, p. 9.</ref>
===The medieval church=== During the [[Middle Ages]], Western theologians such as [[Anselm of Canterbury]], [[John Scotus Eriugena]], [[Bonaventure]], [[Thomas Aquinas]], [[Nicholas of Cusa]], and [[Bernard of Clairvaux]] touched upon themes such as "the idea of beauty, the vision of God, the image of Christ, the [[iconodule]]-[[iconoclasm|iconoclast]] conflict, and the strong presence of personally grounded and poetic [[doxology|doxologies]]".<ref name="Thiessen59">Thiessen, p. 59.</ref>
===The Reformation=== Concerning aesthetics, the theologians of the 16th century [[Protestant Reformation]] ([[Martin Luther]], [[Jean Calvin]], and [[Huldrych Zwingli]]) dealt primarily with "the theology of the image, in particular, [[idolatry]] and [[iconoclasm]]".<ref name="Thiessen125">Thiessen, p. 125.</ref>
===The 17th - 19th centuries=== Theological aesthetics increased in diversity during this period, with activity such as "the composition of [[hymns]] in [[Protestant]] circles, [[Jonathan Edwards (theologian)|Edwards]]' writing on beauty, the [[Romanticism|Romantic]] artists and intellectuals with their [[panentheism|panentheist]] sensibilities, [[Friedrich Schleiermacher|Schleiermacher]]'s idea of religion as feeling and intuition, the decline of religious art, and the ground-breaking philosophical contributions of thinkers such as [[Edmund Burke|Burke]], [[Alexander Gottlieb Baumgarten|Baumgarten]], [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] and [[Hegel]]."<ref name="Thiessen159">Thiessen, p. 159.</ref>
===The 20th century=== Some major themes which emerged and developed in the 20th century included the question of "how art can function as a source of and in theology"<ref name="Thiessen204">Thiessen, p. 204.</ref> ([[Tillich]], [[Rahner]], [[John Dillenberger|Dillenberger]]), the question of "the art work as a shaper of meaning in today's culture"<ref name="Thiessen205">Thiessen, p. 205.</ref> ([[Frank Burch Brown|Burch Brown]], [[Harvey Cox|Cox]], [[Hans Küng|Küng]]), "the essential role of imagination in theology"<ref name="Thiessen206">Thiessen, p. 206.</ref> ([[William Lynch (theologian)|Lynch]], [[John McIntyre (theologian)|McIntyre]], [[Garrett Green|Green]]), and the beauty of God ([[Gerardus van der Leeuw|van der Leeuw]], [[Karl Barth|Barth]], [[von Balthasar]]). [[Hans Rookmaaker|Rookmaaker]] helpfully sought to provide a reformed Christian critique of art and aesthetics in the cultural and political upheavals of the 1960s in his book 'Modern Art and the Death of a Culture'.

'''Tikal Temple I''' is the designation given to one of the major structures at [[Tikal]], one of the largest cities and [[List of Maya sites|archaeological site]]s of the [[pre-Columbian]] [[Maya civilization]] in [[Mesoamerica]]. It is located in the [[Petén Basin]] region of northern [[Guatemala]]. It also is known as the '''Temple of the Great Jaguar''' because of a [[lintel]] that represents a king sitting upon a jaguar throne.<ref name="Muñoz Cosme 1996, p.302">Muñoz Cosme & Quintana Samayoa 1996, p.302.</ref> An alternative name is the '''Temple of Ah Cacao''', after the ruler buried in the temple.<ref group="nb">''Ah Cacao'' being an earlier nickname for the Tikal ruler Jasaw Chan K'awiil I, whose tomb the temple contains.</ref> Temple I is a typically Petén-styled [[limestone]] [[Mesoamerican pyramids|stepped pyramid structure]] that is dated to approximately 732 AD.
Situated at the heart of a [[World Heritage Site]], the temple is surmounted by a characteristic [[roof comb]], a distinctive [[Maya architecture|Maya architectural]] feature. Building Temple I on the eastern side of the Great Plaza was a significant deviation from the established tradition of building funerary temples just north of the plaza in Tikal's [[North Acropolis, Tikal|North Acropolis]].<ref name=st400>Sharer & Traxler 2006, p.400.</ref><ref name=mg47>Martin & Grube 2000, p.47.</ref>
==Structure==
The structure is a funerary temple associated with [[Jasaw Chan K'awiil I]], a [[Mesoamerican chronology|Classic Period]] ruler of the [[polity]] based at Tikal, who ruled from AD 682–734.<ref>Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.313, 397.</ref> The tomb of this ruler has been located by archaeologists deep within the structure,<ref>Martin and Grube 2000, pp.45–47.</ref> the tomb having been built first with the temple being raised over it. Construction of both were overseen by Jasaw Chan K'awiil's son and heir [[Yik'in Chan K'awiil]].<ref name=st397>Sharer & Traxler 2006, pp.397–400.</ref> Jasaw Chan K'awiil probably planned the building of the temple long before his death.<ref name=st400/> The temple rises in nine stepped levels, which may be symbolic of the nine levels of the underworld.<ref>Miller 2001, pp.132–133.</ref> The temple has grooved moldings and inset corners. A steep staircase climbs the temple to the summit shrine.<ref>Fuente et al 1999, p.145.</ref>
[[Image:Pyramid, Tikal, Guatemala.jpg|thumb|left|Temple I, seen from the northwest]]
The temple rises {{convert|47|m|ft|sp=us}} over the Great Plaza.<ref name=mg47/> The pyramid is topped by a funerary shrine, containing finely carved wooden lintels, the execution of which probably was overseen by Jasaw Chan K'awiil as part of his plans for his funerary monument.<ref name=st400/> The lintels were carved from [[sapodilla]] wood and one of them, Lintel 3, once was painted red.<ref>Coe 1962, p.494. Coe 1967, 1988, p.29.</ref> Sapodilla (''Manilkara zapota'') is a very hard red-brown wood available locally.<ref name="Coe 1967, 1988, p.29">Coe 1967, 1988, p.29.</ref> The lintels were formed from planks of this wood set into small niches fashioned into the walls forming the three doorways; the outermost lintel was smooth, but the central lintel was carved intricately from four planks. Two of these planks were removed in the nineteenth century and their location now is unknown.<ref name="Coe 1967, 1988, p.29"/> The other two were removed by [[Alfred Maudslay]] and shipped to the [[British Museum]], where they now are warehoused.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?people=41468&peoA=41468-3-9 British Museum Collection (1)]. [https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=3333142&partId=1&searchText=Am,Maud,G.T.2786&page=1 British Museum Collection (2)]. [http://www.tikalpark.com/generalinfo.htm Website of Tikal National Park]</ref> The scene carved onto one lintel shows a seated figure with an enormous serpent rising above him.<ref name="Coe 1967, 1988, p.29"/>
The shrine bears a high roof comb decorated with a sculpture of the seated king, Jasaw Chan K'awiil, although it now is difficult to discern.<ref name=mg47/><ref>Miller 2001, p.134.</ref> The roof comb consists of two parallel structures with an enclosed, vaulted hollow between them, which reduces the weight of the construction,.<ref name="Coe 1967, 1988, p.28">Coe 1967, 1988, p.28.</ref> The weight of this heavy superstructure is borne through the spine of the temple.<ref name=mg47/> The front of the roof comb was finished with stone blocks carved to represent the enormous figure of the king, flanked by scrolls and serpents.<ref name="Coe 1967, 1988, p.28"/> It originally supported molded plaster decoration as well.<ref>Fuente et al 1999, pp.145–146.</ref> The shrine contains three narrow, dark chambers that were accessible only through a single doorway.<ref>Miller 2001, p.134. Coe 1967, 1988, p.29.</ref> The three rooms were arranged one behind the other, and had high [[Corbel arch|corbel-vaulted]] ceilings, braced by wooden beams. The beams were fashioned from sapodilla, the wood that was used in the lintels.<ref name="Coe 1967, 1988, p.29"/>
Temple I was reused in the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Postclassic Period]]. The Late Classic burial shaft was reopened apparently, and a new burial made inside. The offerings accompanying the new burial included [[censer]]s of a type found in [[Mayapán]] and two [[pottery|ceramic]] types that were widespread in Petén during the Postclassic. The type of censer associated with the new burial was not used after the fifteenth century.<ref>Coe 1962, pp.482–483.</ref>
==Royal tomb== The tomb of Jasaw Chan K'awiil I was discovered by archaeologists in 1962. It was entered through the roof of the tomb after exploratory tunneling from the bottom of the temple stairway.<ref name=mg47/><ref name=st397/><ref>Drew 1999, p.277.</ref> The tomb has been labeled as Burial 116 by archaeologists. It is a large vaulted chamber deep within the pyramid, below the level of the Great Plaza. Over half of the chamber is occupied by the masonry bench supporting the king's body and his jewelry. The king's remains had been laid on a woven mat and the tomb contained rich offerings of jaguar skins, [[jadeite]] objects, painted ceramics, rare [[spondylus]] shells, [[pearl]]s, mirrors, and other works of art.<ref name=mg47/><ref name=st397/><ref>Drew 1999, pp.277–278.</ref> The body of the king was covered with large quantities of [[jade]] ornaments including an enormous necklace with 114 especially large beads, as depicted in sculpted portraits of the king, and weighing {{convert|3.9|kg|lb}}.<ref name=mg47/><ref name=st397/>
One of the outstanding pieces recovered from the tomb was an ornate jade [[mosaic]] vessel with the lid bearing a sculpted portrait of the king. Also accompanying the burial was a series of 37 finely carved human bones bearing inscribed [[Maya script|hieroglyphic]] texts, arranged in a pile by the king's right foot.<ref name=mg47/><ref name=st397/><ref>Drew 1999, p.278.</ref> One refers to Tikal's allies, including [[Copán]] and [[Palenque]]; others include the king's name and parentage. One contains a carved portrait of a captive, Ox Ha Te Ixil, who was a vassal of Tikal's great enemy [[Calakmul]]. There also are scenes that show the [[Maya maize god|maize deity]] being carried to the underworld in a canoe. One of the bones contains a lengthy list of the death dates of foreign nobles.<ref name=st397/>
==Modern history== Tikal was discovered in 1848. In 1877 various pieces were looted from the major temples at Tikal, including pieces of Temple I.<ref name="Muñoz Cosme 1996, p.302"/> [[Alfred P. Maudslay]] first mapped the centre of Tikal in 1881–1882, marking the five major temples on his sketch, including Temple I, although he named the major temples alphabetically, ranging from A through to E. [[Teoberto Maler]] carried out the first [[topography|topographical]] survey of the site in 1895, naming Temple I as the "First Great Temple". [[Alfred Tozzer]] carried out another survey in 1911 and generally followed Maler's naming conventions; it was he who abbreviated the name to Temple I.<ref name="Muñoz Cosme 1996, p.302"/>
In 1955, the [[University of Pennsylvania]] began its Tikal Project, carrying out archaeological investigations of the ruins and preparing them to be opened for tourism, which included work on Temple I and Temple II. The project was overseen by Aubrey Trik and George Guillemin.<ref name="Muñoz Cosme 1996, pp.302-3">Muñoz Cosme & Quintana Samayoa 1996, pp.302–3.</ref> The tomb under the temple was not discovered until 1962, by Aubrey Trik of the University of Pennsylvania.<ref>Coe 1999, p.124.</ref> The work on Temple I lasted until 1964.<ref name="Muñoz Cosme 1996, pp.302-3"/>
In 1986 the Proyecto Nacional Tikal (PRONAT) carried out repairs to cracks in the roof of the temple.<ref>Muñoz Cosme & Quintana Samayoa 1996, p.303.</ref>
As part of the [[2012 phenomenon]], modern Maya held a fire ceremony on 21 December 2012 at dawn in the main plaza in front of the temple. Guatemalan and foreign priests led the ceremony, asking for unity, peace and the end of discrimination and racism, with the hope that the new cycle that begins will be a "new dawn" for them. About 3,000 people participated in the event.<ref>Grupo Nación 2012.</ref>

'''United States of China''' ([[Traditional Chinese]]: 中華合衆國; [[Simplified Chinese]]: 中华合众国; [[Hanyu Pinyin]]: Zhonghua Hezhongguo) is a political concept first devised in the early 1920s by [[Chen Jiongming]] of a [[federalism|federalized]] [[China]] modeled closely after the [[United States of America]]. Given the political, social and linguistic realities of China in the [[warlord]] period, Chen Jiongming believed that a federalist approach was the only feasible way to eventually establish a united, [[democratic republic]]. Beginning with [[Guangdong]] as a model state, he wanted to organize a "United States of China in the manner of the American experience" through negotiation with federalists from all parts of the country (New York Times June 27, 1922).
The introduction of [[Special Economic Zones of the People's Republic of China|Special Economic Zones]] since the 1980s have led to the development of several distinct regional economies within the [[People's Republic of China]], such as the [[Pearl River Delta]], [[Yangtze River Delta]], and the [[Bohai Circle]]. Several of these regions have economies the size of small developed nations. Some scholars who use the term United States of China argue that during the process of [[Chinese economic reform]] the People's Republic has evolved into a de facto federal state in which these economic regions have wide discretion to implement policy goals which are set by the PRC central government and in which provinces and localities actively compete with each other in order to advance economically.

{{for|the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan|Institute for Social Research (University of Michigan)}} {{Infobox organization | name = Institut für Sozialforschung | former name = | image = Institut für Sozialforschung Logo.svg | image_border = | size = 160px | alt = Logo of Institut für Sozialforschung | caption = | map = | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = IfS | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date and age|1923}} | founder = [[Felix Weil]] | type = | status = Foundation | purpose = | headquarters = [[Frankfurt am Main]] | location = | coords = {{coord|50.118414|8.65385|type:landmark_region:DE-HE}} | services = | membership = | language = | leader_title = | leader_name = [[Axel Honneth]] | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers= | slogan = | website = {{URL|http://www.ifs.uni-frankfurt.de/}} | remarks = | footnotes = }} The '''Institute for [[social research|Social Research]]''' ({{lang-de|Institut für Sozialforschung}}, '''IfS''') is a research organization for [[sociology]] and [[continental philosophy]], best known as the institutional home of the [[Frankfurt School]] and [[critical theory]].
==History== [[Image:InstitutfuerSozialforschung3.jpg|180px|thumb|right|The current building of the Institute for Social Research, at Senckenberganlage 26 in [[Frankfurt am Main|Frankfurt]] {{coord|50.118414|8.65385|type:landmark_region:DE_source:enwiki| display=inline}}]] The Institute was founded in [[Frankfurt am Main]] in 1923, where it was (and {{As of|2005|lc=on}} once again is) affiliated with the [[University of Frankfurt am Main]]. It was founded by [[Felix Weil]], a student of the [[Marxist philosopher]] [[Karl Korsch]], with an endowment provided by Weil's wealthy father [[Hermann Weil]]. Its first director, [[Kurt Albert Gerlach]], died before making his mark, and was swiftly followed by [[Carl Grünberg]], a Marxist historian who gathered together fellow "orthodox" [[Marxist]]s at the Institute, including his former pupil [[Henryk Grossman]]. Grünberg was followed by co-founder [[Friedrich Pollock]].
Following a non-fatal heart attack, Grünberg was succeeded in 1930 by [[Max Horkheimer]]. Horkheimer rapidly became the guiding spirit of the Frankfurt School, a group of thinkers that was born under his directorship at the Institute. Horkheimer edited the group's journal ''Zeitschrift für Sozialforschung'' (Journal for Social Research) and wrote essays defining a [[critical theory of society]].
The growing influence of the Nazis led the founders to decide in September 1930 to prepare to move the Institute out of Germany, by establishing a branch in Geneva and moving the funds to the Netherlands.<ref>"The Origins of Critical Theory: An interview with Leo Lowenthal" by {{Interlanguage link multi|Helmut Dubiel|de}} in ''Telos'' 49</ref> In 1933, after the rise of [[Hitler]], the Institute left [[Germany]] for [[Geneva]] and then in 1934 moved to [[New York City]]. In New York it became affiliated with [[Columbia University]], and its journal ''[[Zeitschrift für Sozialforschung]]'' was renamed ''[[Studies in Philosophy and Social Science]]''. It was there that much of the important work of the Frankfurt School thinkers began to emerge, and the Institute's residence in New York was likely partly accountable for its work's favorable reception in American and English [[academia]].
The Institute re-opened in Frankfurt in 1951 under the direction of Pollock.
The Institute has been both a research enterprise and, during its Frankfurt periods, a provider of instruction in sociology at the university there. The current director is [[Axel Honneth]].
[[Image:UniversityofFrankfurt2.jpg|150px|thumb|right|The University of Frankfurt am Main]]
